title: Former Aetna CEO Resigns From CVS Health Board
summary: Mr. Bertolini said earlier he was willing to continue serving but 'board thought otherwise'. Former Aetna Inc. Chief Executive Mark Bertolini resigned from the board of CVS Health Corp. , after the company said Monday he wouldn't stand for re-election later this year.

title: The Bernie Sanders Experience
summary: His supporters come for his 'authenticity' and to hear him rail against greed and corruption, not to make up their minds.. Manchester, N.H.

title: 'The Wire' Is Finished, but Baltimore Still Bleeds
summary: The murder rate in America's deadliest big city is twice that of increasingly violent Mexico.. Baltimore rang in the New Year with crime-scene tape and blood stains. Although 2019's murder toll isn't final yet, the city hit a 25-year high with 348 killings. In 1993, when Baltimore notched its all-time high of 353 killings, Charm City had 130,000 more residents than today. In 2020, Baltimore is shrinking as well as being violent and corrupt.

title: From Washington to Wuhan, All Eyes Are on Xi
summary: China's leader knows that his reputation for competence is on the line.. In October 1911, a virus erupted in Wuhan, China. Revolutionaries opposed to foreign control of China's railways stormed a military garrison, easily defeating imperial forces and revealing the weakness of the ruling Qing dynasty. Known as the Wuchang Uprising, the political virus quickly spread. Three months later the Chinese Revolution toppled the Manchu rulers and ushered in the Republic of China. Today, Wuhan is at the center of the coronavirus outbreak, and the effect on the People's Republic of China may prove to be just as revolutionary.

title: New Bronx Stadium Within Reach for Major League Soccer's NYC FC
summary: Proposed plan would include affordable housing, a school and shops. New York City's major-league soccer team moved a step closer to a deal for a home stadium in the Bronx.

title: Earth to Billionaires: Finding Life Is Space's Final Frontier
summary: Evidence is growing for extraterrestrial life in our solar system, and exploration is cheap.. Are you a billionaire looking to improve the world while immortalizing your name? Are you secretly envious that Richard Branson and Jeff Bezos might make spaceflight routine, or that Elon Musk might put humans on Mars? Look no further for your claim to eternal fame and glory. You have the chance to own humanity's next big space feat: proving the existence of extraterrestrial life.

title: Winning a 5G Battle but Not the War
summary: An FCC chief outsmarts the swamp but the U.S. has not solved the puzzle of competing with China.. This column hereby rescinds its Tom Wheeler award to Ajit Pai, chairman of Federal Communications Commission. (Don't misunderstand. The award is distinctly uncoveted.)

title: In New Jersey, Four Chinese Nationals Are Monitored for Coronavirus
summary: Gov. Phil Murphy says hospital is following protocols, risk to residents is low. Four Chinese nationals were being monitored for symptoms of coronavirus at a New Jersey hospital Friday after health officials screened more than two dozen passengers aboard a recently docked cruise ship.

title: Democratic Debate in New Hampshire: What Time Is It, and Who Qualified?
summary: After the chaos in Iowa, candidates look to the event as chance to persuade voters they can beat Trump. The Democratic debate Friday in New Hampshire comes on the heels of the debacle in Iowa, where results from the party's caucuses were delayed because of technical mishaps.

title: After Devastating Fire, How Will the Vinyl Industry Cope?
summary: Apollo Masters is one of only two producers of lacquers in the world; vinyl industry experts worry about global supply chain. Vinyl records have made a comeback over the past decade, beloved by music fans who prefer what they say is a more authentic sound quality. But how easy they will be to come by is in question after a fire ripped through a little-known California manufacturing plant.

title: China's Leader Wages a War on Two Fronts-Viral and Political
summary: Resume Subscription. BEIJING-Faced with a coronavirus outbreak that so far has killed 630 people and infected more than 31,000 world-wide, China's President Xi Jinping has mobilized the vast state machinery.

title: Two Top IMF Officials Depart After New Chief Takes Charge
summary: Moves give Trump administration a chance to bolster its influence on world economic policy. The International Monetary Fund announced the departure of two senior officials as its new chief, Kristalina Georgieva, seeks to put her own stamp on the lender of last resort to countries in economic crisis.

title: J.B. Hunt CFO to Retire as Company Faces Uncertain U.S. Shipping Market
summary: David Mee has worked at the trucking and logistics company for nearly 30 years. J.B. Hunt Transport Services Inc. said Friday its finance chief, David Mee, will retire, a move that comes as the transportation company navigates an uncertain U.S. shipping market and grapples with an operating loss in its freight brokerage business.

title: Edited Video of Pelosi Ripping Trump's Speech Renews Debate Over Manipulated Content
summary: House speaker's aide to Facebook spokesman: 'what planet are you living on?'. President Trump posted a heavily edited video attacking House Speaker Nancy Pelosi this week, sparking a feud highlighting the gray areas that persist about what manipulated content is permissible on social media.

title: Earnings Are Beating Expectations, but Rewards Are Scarce
summary: Already-high share prices, worries about coronavirus temper investors' enthusiasm for strong reports. Companies that top earnings expectations aren't getting much reward from shareholders.

title: 'Author in Chief' Review: The Oval Office Book Club
summary: Our presidents ranked not by their political achievements but by their literary chops.. John Adams, the stoutest but thinnest-skinned of the Founders, compulsively responded to what he saw as "the torment of a perpetual volcano of slander, pouring on my flesh all my life." As president, centuries before the covfefe of internet communication, he made his ire twitteringly ubiquitous by "firing off dozens of public letters that were reprinted around the country." So Craig Fehrman reminds us in his delightfully instructive new study of presidential authorship. Expelled from the White House in 1801, Adams began to write a self-justifying memoir but kept settling so many scores that after 440 pages he'd yet to reach his years in the top job.

title: 'Weather' Review: Happy Thoughts?
summary: A moving and original novel that captures the life of a selfless wife and mother, a life that's not ideal but never boring.. To be honest, the feeling I had when I first read "Dept. of Speculation," Jenny Offill's breakthrough 2014 novel, was mild resentment. The book's narrator-a Brooklyn-based wife and mother who grapples with the inevitable narrowing of life, with all of its attending gifts and disappointments-felt just so familiar. Her takes and observations were keen, insightful and also familiar. And the book was so spare, more like a series of notes than a full-fledged novel, that I suppose I was jealous that Ms. Offill pulled it off. As a similarly aging, similarly ambitious, similarly frustrated, similarly observant Brooklyn-based woman, I may have wondered (in that whiny voice reserved for personal questions of dubious injustice): Well, where is my acclaimed book?

title: 'Sidney Lumet: A Life' Review: Man of Action
summary: In Lumet's ﬁlms, big moral themes-truth, loyalty, justice-play out amid the everyday chaos of work and life.. Sidney Lumet, who died in 2011 at the age of 86, was a remarkably prolific artist: In a 55-year directing career he made a total of 43 movies and some 75 television plays, movies and episodes. Before that he had spent a dozen years as an actor. An output of that size cannot be uniformly excellent, and Lumet's isn't. But his best movies are very, very good: "12 Angry Men," his very first film, is a dazzling exercise in the use of the camera, still studied in film schools; and then there are "Long Day's Journey Into Night," "The Pawnbroker," "Serpico," "Dog Day Afternoon," "Prince of the City," "The Verdict," "Before the Devil Knows You're Dead" and best of all "Network," even more powerful now, in the crazed media climate of the 21st century, than it was in the 20th.

title: After Democrats' Caucus Woes, Trump Praises Iowa, New Hampshire
summary: Both of the early-nominating states could be in play in the November election. As Democrats seek to move past Iowa's caucus chaos, President Trump is praising the state-along with the fellow early-voting New Hampshire-as he calls for them to remain atop the primary calendar.

title: Airbus in Advanced Talks to Acquire Bombardier Stake in A220 Program
summary: A deal for Bombardier's 34% stake could be reached as early as next week. Airbus SE is in advanced talks to acquire Bombardier Inc.'s remaining stake in a commercial jet family that the Canadian company once said would transform it into a major global aviation player, people familiar with the matter said.

title: 'Dark Arts' and 'Codebreaker': The Origins of the Houston Astros Cheating Scheme
summary: MLB Commissioner Rob Manfred's previously undisclosed letter to Astros GM Jeff Luhnow details the team's spreadsheet and algorithm to steal signs in one of the biggest scandals in baseball history. On Sept. 22, 2016, an intern in the Houston Astros organization showed general manager Jeff Luhnow a PowerPoint presentation that featured the latest creation by the team's high-tech front office: an Excel-based application programmed with an algorithm that could decode the opposing catchers' signs. It was called "Codebreaker."

title: U.S. Stocks Fall, But Post Big Weekly Gains
summary: The Dow and S&P 500 have biggest weekly point gains since June 2019. U.S. stocks posted their biggest weekly gains in months, capping a volatile period that included stronger-than-expected data and uncertainty about the economic impact of the viral outbreak in China.

title: FedEx to Start Mixing Express, Ground Operations
summary: Delivery giant, which long kept its networks separate, will use Ground drivers to take some Express packages to residences. FedEx Corp. will start handing off some of its Express packages to its Ground division for last-mile delivery, bringing the two operations closer together as the company struggles with the surge in e-commerce shipments.

title: House Passes Puerto Rico Disaster-Aid Bill, Reigniting Fight With Trump
summary: Debate over use of funds continues after warehouse full of supplies was discovered last month on island racked by earthquakes. WASHINGTON-The House passed a roughly $4.7 billion disaster-aid package Friday as Democrats pushed to finance earthquake-recovery efforts in Puerto Rico, though the bill wasn't likely to advance past the chamber because of partisan divisions on how aid is managed on the island.

title: U.S. Government Bond Yields Fall on Uncertain Economic Outlook
summary: Bond prices rise following disappointing data out of the eurozone. U.S. government bond prices rose Friday, as poor European economic data and continued coronavirus fears outweighed a solid U.S. jobs report.

title: Panama Papers Case to Net First U.S. Conviction
summary: Harald Joachim von der Goltz, who was charged with using the services of Panamanian law firm Mossack Fonseca to circumvent U.S. tax laws, will plead guilty, federal prosecutors say. A German businessman charged with evading U.S. taxes as part of an investigation sparked by a trove of leaked documents known as the Panama Papers will plead guilty, federal prosecutors said.

summary: State attorney general calls suspension of trusted-traveler program 'political retribution'. title: Oil Falls for Fifth Week as Investors Weigh Coronavirus Fallout

summary: The myth of Orpheus told with mixed results in Los Angeles; political satire transported to a modern setting in New York.. Los Angeles

summary: The bank held Brian Moynihan's pay steady for 2019, a year when the stock jumped more than 40%. Bank of America Corp. greenlighted a $26.5 million pay package for its top executive in 2019 after the bank's shares marked their best run in years.

title: Business Meeting at Luxury Singapore Hotel Becomes Latest Coronavirus Focus
summary: Authorities try to monitor participants at Grand Hyatt event, while Singapore raises its disease alert level. SINGAPORE-For three days in January, 109 people from different countries gathered for a business meeting organized by a U.K.-based company at the Grand Hyatt Singapore, a luxury hotel in the heart of the city's main shopping area. They shook hands and ate meals together. Then they went home.

title: Appeals Court Tosses Democrats' Emoluments Lawsuit Against Trump
summary: Court panel says Democratic lawmakers don't have legal standing to bring case. WASHINGTON-A federal appeals court threw out a lawsuit by more than 200 Democratic members of Congress that alleged President Trump was improperly profiting from his presidency.

summary: Mexican president redeploys elite marines force he had largely sidelined. Mexican President Andrés Manuel López Obrador, under pressure from the Trump administration, has beefed up his strategy to fight drug cartels, including bringing the marines, Mexico's elite security force, back to the front lines of the drug war.

title: Backlash From Parents Delays Effort to Integrate Queens Schools
summary: Schedule for series of public workshops has been tossed and Education Department hasn't offered a new one. An effort by New York City officials to diversify middle schools in a swath of Queens has been delayed after outcry from parents and heated public meetings.

summary: Nearly three of four Americans who became newly employed in recent months came from outside the labor force. A tight U.S. labor market is drawing Americans off the sidelines at a record rate.

title: Saudi Arabia, Kuwait Set to Restart Oil Output in Neutral Zone
summary: Plan to restart follows resolution of five-year dispute between the countries. Saudi Arabia is set Monday to restart oil production in a long-dormant operation it shares with Kuwait, oil officials said Friday.

title: Coronavirus Fallout Threatens Auto Industry's Supply Chain
summary: Idled plants pose another challenge to auto makers already dealing with slowing sales, declining profitability. Disruptions caused by the coronavirus outbreak have forced auto makers and their suppliers to idle plants across China, rattling the industry's global supply chain and posing another challenge for companies already facing slowing sales and declining profitability.

title: A Symphony to Link Africa and America
summary: William Levi Dawson's 'Negro Folk Symphony' is a celebration of the vernacular in a traditional, European form.. In 1926 the African-American poet Langston Hughes wrote a seminal Harlem Renaissance essay, "The Negro Artist and the Racial Mountain." The mountain "standing in the way of any true Negro art in America," he declared, was an urge "toward whiteness," a "desire to pour racial individuality into the mold of American standardization, and to be as little Negro and as much American as possible." Hughes cited, as an antidote, "the eternal tom-tom beating in the Negro soul": jazz and the blues.

title: Hospitals Pushed to the Brink in Wuhan: 'I Just Want to Save His Life'
summary: Resume Subscription. WUHAN, China-Patients packed the waiting room at Wuhan's Tongji Hospital on Friday, intravenous drips in their arms. Medical staff wheeled patients slowly through the crowd. In the hallways, the sick lay curled up on cots, hooked to oxygen tanks.

title: In China, Anger Simmers Over Coronavirus Doctor's Death
summary: Dr. Li Wenliang, who died of the disease, was one of the first to warn of it before he was questioned by police. BEIJING-China pledged "thorough investigations" into the death of Li Wenliang, a doctor who raised early alarms about a new respiratory virus, as public anger built across the country over the government's handling of the coronavirus epidemic that has spread quickly across China and around the world.

title: Democrats Need to Disguise Their Leftness
summary: Mr. Emanuel is richer, smarter, and more powerful than I will ever be, but he is a fool if he believes his party now "shares in the mission of using the government's tools to serve those who have been left behind.". Regarding Rahm Emanuel's "Democrats May Be Blowing Their Chance" (op-ed, Feb. 1): Mr. Emanuel is richer, smarter and more powerful than I will ever be, but he is a fool if he believes his party now "share[s] in the mission of using the government's tools to serve those who have been left behind."

summary: It has been too many years since this country has taken such a positive course for the betterment of our citizens and, as it will turn out, the world.. title: 'Finest Hours' Seem to Be In Short Supply These Days
summary: Sen. Lamar Alexander's position on new evidence in the impeachment trial might be his finest hour, it won't stand up very well against the example set by his fellow Tennesseean, Sen. Howard Baker, during the Watergate era.. Regarding your editorial "Lamar Alexander's Finest Hour" (Feb. 3): Although, as you say, Sen. Lamar Alexander's position on new evidence in the impeachment trial might be his finest hour, it won't stand up very well against the example set by his fellow Tennesseean, Sen. Howard Baker, during the Watergate era. President Richard Nixon won 61% of the popular vote and carried 49 states, yet no one in those days decried impeachment as voter nullification.

title: Bernie Sanders Deserved to Have a Much Better Week
summary: The train wreck in Iowa cost the firebrand senator crucial momentum. Malevolent forces in the Democratic Party establishment may or may not be conspiring against Sen. Bernie Sanders. But it's hard to resist the conclusion that events are.

summary: Crackdown in futures markets is yielding new wins for prosecutors, but several coming trials will show if tactic is ultimately successful. A yearslong crackdown on cheating in futures markets is yielding new wins for the government, but several trials to come will show whether the Justice Department's focus on a tactic known as "spoofing" is ultimately successful.

title: Parcel, Warehouse Companies Added 20,000 U.S. Jobs Last Month
summary: Surge in post-holiday logistics payrolls is led by operations tied to growing e-commerce demand. U.S. logistics hiring soared in January on continued strength in the consumer economy, with delivery and warehousing companies adding 20,000 jobs in sectors tied to e-commerce.

title: The Iowa App and the Clinton Cabal
summary: There's money to be made in "progressive" politics.. What do you get when you combine Team Clinton's business savvy with panicked Democrats eager to counter Donald Trump's use of digital technology? Behold the Iowa Democratic Party's caucus reporting app.

title: Former Pimco CEO Sentenced to Nine Months in Prison in College Admissions Case
summary: Resume Subscription. BOSTON-Douglas Hodge, the former chief executive of bond giant Pacific Investment Management Co., was sentenced Friday to nine months in prison, the longest sentence to date for any parent charged in the sprawling college-admissions cheating case.

title: U.S. Needs Better Spectrum Policy to Win in 5G World
summary: To speed up 5G, we need to throw out spectrum auctions entirely.. Daniel Goldin accurately describes an extremely serious problem ("Keep 5G Safe From Chinese Domination," op-ed, Jan. 30). He points out the severe damage created by the lengthy spectrum auction process, but I maintain the problem is the spectrum auction process itself. Since the methodology was introduced years ago, it has burdened American companies with monumental debt, forcing them to defer critical technology research.

title: Seattle Policy Will Destroy Affordable Rental Housing
summary: When the city of Seattle made it illegal for landlords to run criminal record checks on prospective tenants, I stopped renting units that became vacant.. Regarding Ethan Blevins's "Seattle and the State Supreme Court Wage War on Property Rights" (Cross Country, Feb. 1): When the city of Seattle made it illegal for landlords to run criminal record checks on prospective tenants, I stopped renting units that became vacant. Under Washington state case law, courts have held the landlord to be responsible for providing safe housing. So with one bad tenant in your building who harms other tenants, the landlord can be sued and lose all of his or her financial assets. This law fast tracked my decision to get out of this business and sell my properties.

title: Fed Officials Likely to Take Comfort From Jobs Report
summary: Latest employment figures offer little reason for central bank to change make-no-moves stance. The solid January employment report should comfort Federal Reserve officials about the state of the U.S. economy before the recent threats to global growth surfaced from the outbreak of the coronavirus in China last month.

title: Baseball Shouldn't Sneer at Professional Wrestling
summary: How dare Fay Vincent compare baseball to professional wrestling. Professional wrestlers don't cheat, whine while making millions or complain about living in an unwoke country.. Regarding former Commissioner of Baseball Fay Vincent's "Is Baseball Turning Into Pro Wrestling?" (op-ed, Jan. 27): How dare Mr. Vincent compare baseball to professional wrestling. Professional wrestlers don't cheat, whine while making millions or complain about living in an unwoke country.

summary: EU is investigating the company's alleged infringement of competition law through "certain practices restricting cross-border trade". Mondelez International Inc. said it is being investigated by the European Union over allegations the company has violated competition law.

title: 'Bachelor' Fans Look to Venmo for Proof of Love
summary: Payment app plays spoiler for 'The Bachelor' watchers. Mobile apps are already playing spoiler to traditional payment methods. They may be doing it to reality-television shows, too.

title: Outlier Artists Shine in London Auctions
summary: Record prices for Magritte and Lempicka belie caution among many collectors; Chinese buyers are absent amidst coronavirus outbreak. Three months after New York's lackluster fall auctions hinted at softness in the art market, collectors are navigating the sales underway in London now with caution, spooked in part by the coronavirus outbreak in China.

title: Sandra Boynton Writes Children's Books That Don't Condescend
summary: The author of such classics as 'Moo, Baa, La La La!' and 'But Not the Hippopotamus' combines wit, silliness and a deep empathy for the emotions of her young readers. To celebrate her recent books "Silly Lullaby" and "Dinosnores," the beloved children's author Sandra Boynton threw not a book party but a pajama party. At a New York store on a Chelsea morning, three of Ms. Boynton's four adult children-fresh-faced, cheerful and vigorous-shimmied onstage in flannel jammies near large cardboard cutouts of Ms. Boynton's charmingly bewildered cows and other animals. They led a roomful of rapt children and beaming parents in the titular lullaby, which is as silly as promised: "Go to sleep, my zoodle, my fibblety-fitsy foo. Go to sleep, sweet noodle. The owl is whispering 'Moo.'" A long line of short readers waited for Ms. Boynton to sign their board books, often lovingly battered and bitten. "This is like meeting Bono," one mother said happily.

title: St. Luke's Hospital Rebrands as Mount Sinai Morningside
summary: Move is intended to improve facility image, which is dented by underinvestment. Mount Sinai St. Luke's hospital is taking a new name in an effort to shake off a dated image of itself.

title: Why Do We Love to Hate the Oscars?
summary: Hollywood's annual self-congratulation ceremony is always a bit dull. I can't wait to watch!. The Oscars will be awarded on Sunday, and I bet you have a big, loud opinion about it. Everyone loves to hate on the Academy's shiny gold statue parade-it's too this, it's too that, too much politics, rah, rah, rah, yadda, yadda-but then mostly everyone always winds up watching at least a little bit of the show. I think you will, too.

SOME SKIERS LEAVE phones and their distractions at the lodge, the better to embrace nature. But the slopes are infinitely more rewarding with full access to these four apps-just be sure to tuck your phone into a warm pocket.

TOKYO-Japan reported a tripling of cases of novel coronavirus among people on a quarantined cruise liner, as the largest known cluster of infection outside China provides clues to how easily the virus spreads in confined conditions.

summary: Investors have been diving into the bond market like never before. Tesla Inc.'s stock isn't the only hot asset.

summary: English soccer's one-horse title race is a ratings bonanza. LONDON-The Premier League title race hasn't really been much of a race in more than six months-it's more like a Liverpool parade that 19 other teams were invited to.

title: 'Thomas Mann's War' Review: The Man and the Moment
summary: The author of 'The Magic Mountain' made barnstorming tours across the American prairie, rallying support for the cause of liberal democracy.. On March 12, 1933,Thomas Mann took a phone call that changed his life. He and his wife, Katia, were in the tranquil Swiss resort of Arosa, recuperating after a lecture tour around Europe. On the line was his daughter Erika: On no account, she told him, should he return to Germany. Hitler's regime was after him. The tip-off had come from the family chauffeur, Hans Holtzman, who knew what he was talking about-he was a Nazi informant struck by a pang of conscience.

title: Five Best: Jonathan Rosenberg on Music, Politics and Society
summary: From the author, most recently, of 'Dangerous Melodies: Classical Music in America From the Great War Through the Cold War.'. By Joseph Horowitz (1994)

title: 'The Falcon Thief' Review: Cuckoo for Raptors
summary: The life and career of the 'Pablo Escobar' of bird eggs, a daring smuggler who once dangled from a helicopter to rob nests.. 'Everyone lies about sex," a learned courtesan named Priscilla says in a novel by David Mamet. Only one subject attracts more liars. "Would you be surprised," she asks, "to know that it is birdwatching?"

title: 'Cat Tale' Review: From the Brink of Extinction
summary: In the mid-90s it was believed that Florida's panther population had dwindled down to six, with only one female.. Environmental reporting can often seem like a stint on the obituary desk. Vanishing wetlands, disappearing rainforests and thinning coral reefs mean writing a lot about what's lost, perhaps never to return.

title: Fiction: The Trickster Hero of the Thirty Years' War
summary: On the road with Tyll Eulenspiegel, the devil's disciple of Germanic legend.. If you're going to be a German writer of distinction, at some point in your career you have to dance with the devil. Goethe had "Faust," Thomas Mann had "Doctor Faustus" and his son Klaus, "Mephisto." Now the prodigiously imaginative Daniel Kehlmann, whose 2005 novel "Measuring the World" was a global bestseller, has written "Tyll" (Pantheon, 342 pages, $26.95), which recasts the legend of Tyll Ulenspiegel. In German folklore, Ulenspiegel is a trickster figure, a merry prankster who, since the 16th century, has figured in low comic tales, sophisticated satires and a tone poem by Richard Strauss. In Mr. Kehlmann's novel (ably translated by Ross Benjamin) he is a disciple of "the great, great devil," a grinning lord of disorder whose jokes and games have a strange way of presaging the devastation of the Thirty Years' War.

title: Mysteries: Better Dying Through Chemistry
summary: A CIA officer digs up unpleasant memories by investigating the decades-old death of a scientist who conducted biological research during the 1950s.. Washington in 1975 is the principal setting for Paul Vidich's terse and convincing thriller "The Coldest Warrior" (Pegasus, 216 pages, $25.95). CIA officer Jack Gabriel is about to retire from the agency for a job in the private sector, but the new CIA director asks him to stay on and investigate an internal scandal from more than two decades ago.

title: Children's Books: Many Ways of Making Mischief
summary: A new English version of the antic German classic that inspired the funny papers' Katzenjammer Kids.. Children who play malicious pranks on adults in the real world are liable to get themselves expelled or medicated. A worse fate befalls two of the naughtiest boys in all of children's literature, wicked scamps who first appeared in 1865 in the illustrated pages of "Max und Moritz" by the German humorist and artist Wilhelm Busch.

title: Why You Should Never Buy Ski Gear Again
summary: Flying with ski gear is a pain, and even the best equipment depreciates quicker than fast-fashion. Here, why you should rent-never buy-nearly all your slope needs from now on. UNTIL RECENTLY my ski vacations have begun with frustration. I've muscled a mountain of equipment into several duffels for the plane and torched my Amex with baggage fees only to stuff everything into the always-smaller-than-advertised rental car when I land. The only real alternative was renting scuffed-up gear at the resort.
